awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The impact of social factors on the syntactic patterns of code-switching among young adults
awd_abstract_narration:
This study examines spoken and written data among young adults in Morocco to probe the effects of social factors on Moroccan Arabic-French code-switching, the use of two languages in a single conversation. Due to its colonial history, French remains an important language in Morocco but its use today in spoken discourse occurs mainly through code-switching with the vernacular dialect of Arabic. This study will examine, from a linguistic perspective, how speakers integrate these two grammatically diverse languages. While Arabic-French code-switching has been the topic of previous studies, the current project will quantify the rates of French usage among young adults of varied backgrounds to determine how social factors correlate with differences in observed code-switching grammatical patterns. At issue is how bilinguals utilize their linguistic repertoires in varied media and whether conventionalized forms of code-switching can be identified.

40 native speakers of Moroccan Arabic will participate in two task types: 1) spoken conversational tasks and 2) text-based chat via internet. In each task type, participants will be free to discuss any topic(s) of their choice in any language(s) they desire. The inclusion of both oral and written production of the same individuals allows for the identification of emerging linguistic conventions in this traditionally spoken dialect.

The focus of this study is to quantify the extent to which French permeates Arabic discourse and whether or not there are identifiable patterns of French use that correlate with social predictors, such as gender and class. Such an analysis will allow comparison with future research in other geographic areas. Additionally, this investigation will contribute to the study of bilingual language forms more broadly by creating a corpus of spoken and written mixed Moroccan Arabic-French discourse that will be shared with other researchers and adding to an understanding of language use in a post-colonial context.

por.por_cntn:
This study examined code-switching, or the use of two languages in a single utterance, between Moroccan Arabic and French by young adults in Morocco. The overall findings show that these speakers use primarily Moroccan Arabic, with very few French words mixed into their Arabic. The methods and findings of this research are relevant to research within the target community as well as to the broader field of bilingualism due to the fact that the phenomenon of code-switching can be found in a variety of communities and settings.

During the funding period, Rebekah Post completed five months of fieldwork in a large city in central Morocco. This research provided the data for her doctoral dissertation, which was also completed during the funding period. The research included two informal language production tasks, each completed in the same speaker pairs: 1) a spoken conversation and 2) a typed IM (Instant Message) exchange. Each of the speakers then completed a background survey to supply relevant biographical information in order to understand what social factors may impact use of French. The participants also completed a short grammar-based French test as a measure of their French proficiency to determine whether this affected their use of French words. The most frequent French lexical items (or words) present in the conversations were also analyzed to determine whether these words may in fact have become a part of the Moroccan Arabic lexicon.

This project has impact in multiple areas of bilingualism, language contact, and Arabic dialect study. First, the inclusion of a written task provides a picture of the current writing system of Moroccan Arabic, a language variety that does not have a standardized written form and can often be found today using the Arabic or Latin alphabet. In addition, to our knowledge no prior research uses data from the same speakers in two modalities to analyze code-switching; the ability to compare the spoken and written language production by the same speakers then provides an unprecedented understanding of the similarities and differences in these two language production modalities. Finally, the full corpus will be freely shared with interested researchers in order to allow a deeper investigation of any of the issues present in the corpus; spoken and written Moroccan Arabic, the emerging writing system, the use of French and English by young Moroccans, and the ways in which these participants interact, among other topics. It is hoped that the corpus will be compared to past and future corpora in order to provide a more complete picture of this variety of Arabic.

The results of Rebekah's analysis, detailed in her dissertation, indicate that there are important differences in both the quantity and types of French words used in written and spoken language. In addition, gender seems to play a role in the level of French used in written, but not spoken, language. A positive attitude toward French is correlated with a higher rate of French used by participants in both written and spoken communication, pointing to the importance of personal factors in the use of each language. An unintended finding of this study is confirmation of the rising status of English among young adults in Morocco as many of the participants incorporated English-origin vocabulary into their written and spoken conversations.

Rebekah's dissertation is available freely online for any interested individuals in order to increase access to scholarly works. It can currently be downloaded from Academia.edu by anyone with an internet connection and will soon be freely available via the University of Texas's digital repository.
